This Christmas you'll receive many cards from your family. These cards will have pictures from photography studios with a wintery back drop or pictures of family vacations. Everyone wants to see how much the kids have grown.
We took it a step further. This year my family will receive a card/ornament of us in 3D. We scanned ourselves admiring our recently decorated Christmas tree. Dogs are very hard to scan by the way.
As you can see we printed ourselves out separately from the tree. This way the ornament can be customized. We scanned ourselves and the tree, separately using reconstruct me. Maya was used to build the scene.
Just Print with supports! We used a .18 layer height for bring out the details.

remixed_from.title: Spring-loaded Replicator 2 Drive Arm for a 3mm bearing

description.text: This is a remix 'Spring-loaded Replicator 2 Drive Arm for a 3mm bearing'. I was having sporadic issues with filament slightly thinner than average slipping off of the bearing. The only change to the original design is to remove a slight cone at the bottom of the bearing shaft so that the bearing sat further towards the drive block. It will increase friction on the bearing, but it has solved my issue.

This ornament is designed to represent those delicate glass ornaments we hang on our trees. It was designed to print in translucent PLA plastic allowing not only light to reflect off of it but to pass through it as well.  
The ornament is hollow and shimmers as light bounces off of it. It sort of has a satiny look to it.  
It requires no raft or supports.  
The featured ornament was printed in Natural PLA.

Print with:
  • No rafts or supports needed.
  • 10% infill.
  • Number of Shells: 4 (very important when printing in translucent plastic)
  • Layer Height: 0.20 mm
    • Print, then tear off the tabs at the bottom of the print.
    Hang on Christmas tree and enjoy!

This light is similar to CageLight0 but differs in several ways: the hexagons making the grid are offset so the grid is comprised of only hexagons, the hex grid is circular so it matches the shape of the internal light, and the lamp base is the same as my other LED lamps. It does use the same LED light source - just search for "LED puck light" and you'll find many options. Note that the lamp base includes a cutout for a wall-powered LED light.

This is a challenging part to print because the hex cage is quite thin, so If your printer's hotend is a little wobbly it could knock a piece of the cage off. My next design will be slightly larger and have a more robust hex cage. I printed this one in just under 17 hours at a 0.200 mm layer height.

author: Seb200

description.text: Print your own pair of Zurich Party Glasses
Bill boum articulated (Mario)

Printer:

Dagoma Discovery200

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Watch here: https://youtu.be/j2P6Q-kJKBw

Today's #3DPrintmas model is Voltorb from Pokemon. This was a fun and easy model to create. And I think it turned out looking really great.

I created the model in Fusion 360 by cutting a sphere in half, sketching out the eye details and intersecting them with the top half of the sphere and pushing them in slightly.

Then after printing it out I handed it off to my wife who sanded, primed and painted it. She sprayed the bottom white and did the same for the eye region of the top. Then she use a sponge to dab the red coloring on the top and dab black around the inside edges of both sides. That way, when she glued them together, you could see a faint black line.

Print Settings:
Printer: Da Vinci 1.0 Pro
Filament: Hatchbox PLA
Layer Height: 0.1mm
Infill: 30%
Supports: No
Raft: No

comments.text: Nice. I will make it hollow to hold electronics, a speaker to say "Voltorb" like they do in the Anime, and possibly an electrostatic generator or something to shock people or light up fluorescent bulbs from a distance.

description.text:
A 3D printed Christmas (Holiday) card. Flat-packed for easy postage, the reindeer model can be snapped from the supportive frame and then assembled.

I designed this for Christmas 2015, and got the A6 traditional cards printed professionally. I then 3D printed all the models and attached them to the front of the cars using micro glue dots.

You may need to fiddle with the settings of your printer to make sure the final print fits together well. As you can imagine the tolerances are pretty tiny.

Included with the STL I have added all the 3D renders, which I used for the fronts of the 2D printed cards, and the vector graphics I used for the insides (including instructions).

BONUS Laser cutting version

Due to popular request I have added the files for laser cutting this kit card. It's designed to fit a A6 card front, and use 1.5mm ply stock. There are 4 layers/colours which denote the following cut styles:

  • Red: Simple cut, whichever settings that work on your laser for this material.
  • Black: Dot mode using Red settings with 0.3mm interval and 10mm dot length. This allows the end recipient to pop out the elements to assemble the model.
  • Blue: Light cut/etch, faster and much lower power cut to draw on details and instructions.
  • Green: Dot mode using Red settings with 0.2mm interval and 50mm dot length. This allows you to separate the cut cards from the cutting stock.

If you have trouble please let me know in the comments and I will try to help if I can!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

As the model is quite thin, I would recommend using top and bottom layers to make the infill 100%. Printed mine with different coloured PLA. You will want to print the first layer slower than normal as its quite fiddly and you don't want the parts lifting due to swift nozzle movement.

title: Christmas Light Clip for Wire Frame designs

description.text:
I have holiday lights displayed on decorative wire frames during December, animated by a light controller. (Controller turns lights on/off to make them appear to be animated... santa throwing gifts, and an elf decorating a stocking (shown)).

These "clips" hold 2 different dimension "mini" light bulbs (I use incandescent, but these will likely work with LED). One design is more "rectangular" (clip A) in shape, the other which is more "round" (clip B2) in shape... you'll need to pick the one that most closely represents your light string. Both designs allow for a little larger on one end than the other (light bulb casing narrows near the wire), and this allows these to fit a variety of bulbs, as sliding the bulb down in these will tighten them down.

All are designed to clip tightly into a 12.5 gauge galvanized metal wire which I use as a frame for these light sculptures. I obtained this wire at a local farm and ranch store.

If you want to learn about the lighting controller, I use Renard SS24 controllers designed by and build kits provided through http://www.doityourselfchristmas.com/wiki/index.php?title=Main_Page (Warning, it can be addictive, expensive and time consuming... but so cool).

Good luck, and happy decorating.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Fine

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I prefer to print the "x50" STLs (50 clips) with a narrow brim as the initial (first layer) is very difficult to print without it. You do need to clip each one to separate them but it's fairly easy to do.

Infill really doesn't matter (there isn't much in the design that is infill...)

You may want to print an individual one for sizing beforehand. (see STLs)

description.text:
It is an idea to keep your phone at hand on your car.
This support is designed for my Honda HRV and my Huawei p9 lite with 5 "display with standard cover and can be fixed in the small compartment above the radio.
The cradle can be rotated so you can use your phone as a GPS navigator horizontally or vertically to make calls hands-free safely while driving activating the speakerphone function.
By rotating the cradle you can also access the car stereo controls or air conditioning buttons.
It is however also used on other cars with a free car stereo slot (double-radio frames).
The parts can be printed in PLA or ABS or PETG, depending on which is the maximum temperature reached in summer inside the car.
Set 3 edges to print the craddle to make it more robust.
Supports where needed ... especially in recessed areas.
The two jaws have been printed together in a vertical position arranged longitudinally.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 DIY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50-70
Use a M4 x 50mm screw to assembly the jaws to the central block and a M4x30 screw with a nylonstop nut to assembly the craddle tightening so you can turn it.

The part is designed with onshape cad
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/c79ac5c33f676d22f52ff487/w/aaeb1c0bfb61e0742492d06f/e/b189a52df61ab70fc0ee5441
and shared so anyone having an onshape account can import the original model to adapt it to own phone and car.

title: Ford 427 Cobra Desktop Scale Model 1:5
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here´s a nice model of a Ford 427ci Cobra V8 engine for your dektop.
I found a very detailed CAD database of this engine on GrabCAD. After scaling the model down to around 20% of it´s original size I started the CAD preparation and meshing work (around 100 hours of preparation time) to get this highly detailed model of this legendary engine. The transmission with bellhousing and shifter linkage is also included. As you can see, the modell consists of a large number of
single .stl files (very high polygon 0.5 - 1mm meshing size). That give you the ability to use different colors while printing the parts. Or you can paint the parts before the assembly starts. After printing you have to glue together the parts to get this amazing engine model. Some parts are a little tricky to print! You should have some experience with your printer! See "Print Settings" for some tips!

Now have fun with this amazing model engine!!

If you are interested in a superdetailed "Bug" aircooled Boxer engine, visit my homepage
at https://www.printable-3d-models.com/de/3d-druckbarer-bausatz-vw-kaefer-bus-buggy-motor.html

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

You have to print the files:

accelerator_pump.stl 4x
freeze_plug.stl 4x
fuel_bowl_caps.stl 4x
throttle_linkage.stl 2x
valve_cover.stl 2x
V-Belt.stl 2x
velocity_stacks.stl 8x
weber_carb_body.stl 4x

In most cases you can use the standard resolution of 0.1mm.
Some parts needed a little higher resolution of maybe 0.06mm.
these are:

spark_plug_wires_left.st
spark_plug_wires_right.stl
throttle_linkage.stl
accelerator_pump.stl

The spark wires should be printed upsidedown (terminals which are going to the rotorcap touching the buildplate). Here you have to mess around a little with your support structure settings (overhang angle 30 degrees?!?).
Use the position as provided in .stl file for the headers. Also have a closer look to the support settings.

Assembly Information

Use the rendered images for assembling the engine!!!

the part crankshaft_end.stl is positioned on the lower timing cover (the crankshaft part sticking out of the front of engine). The vibration damper is mouted on this part.

the part accelerator_pump.stl will be glued to the part weber_carb_body.stl. You´ll find the flange on the carb body!
The position of part fuel_bowl_caps.stl is between the intake stacks of part weber_carb_body.stl.

The rest should be clear. If you have questions about assembly, please Email!!

What's better than one cool ornament? A whole box with six of them that's what! I remember as a kid the fun of decorating the tree. Remember those compartmentalized boxes that had the cool glass ornaments in them? This thing is an omage to those boxes of ornaments. Decorating the tree, turning the twinkling lights on, and the regular lamps out, and just enjoying the magical glow of the Christmas tree. This is by far my most challenging entry to the Makerbot ornament contest due to its size. When done printing, it will have produced a compartmentalized box that holds 6 hollow shimmering ornaments which can be removed from the box and hung on a tree. Video of results of first hour printing: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fj1AZf21iQY It took 16 hours and 42 minutes to print this!

It is especially important that your build plate is very level and very clean for this to print correctly. This is a very large print and was designed to print on the large build plate of the Makerbot Replicator 2. If your printer's build plate is too small for this print, check out my Shimmering Ornament in a Box thing: it should fit nicely on most any 3D printer's build plate! Print with:
  • No supports needed.
  • Unlike the other ornament entries I submitted, a raft is really NEEDED here!
  • 10% infill.
  • Number of Shells: 4 (very important when printing in translucent plastic)
  • Layer Height: 0.20 mm
    • Print, pop off the build plate with a tool such as a spatula using one of the slots on the bottom of the box, then tear off the tabs at the bottom of the box. There is a built-in support on the bottom of each ornament: twist them off with a pair of needle-nose pliers. Take the ornaments out of the box and hang them on a Christmas tree and enjoy! Store the ornaments inside the box when you take down your decorations for the season.

comments.text: Thanks! Hope it prints well for you. The shell count was set so no support material would print in the ornament thus obscuring the light passing through it as little as possible.

title: Jig for drilling extra holes for shelves

description.text:
This is a jig for drilling extra holes in wooden shelving systems that uses pegs to locate the shelves. I used it for some old Ikea Billy shelves that use 5 mm pegs. Ikea kitchen shelving may also work with the tool as is, but the tool can also easily be customized for other systems.

Printing is straight forward. I used PLA which has minimum shrinkage issues.

You can use a piece of tape around the drill bit to indicate correct depth. A tip for Billy is to use a 4.9 mm drill instead of 5.0 mm - this gives a nice fit for the pegs.

comments.text: In theory, such an add-on could be made since the banana shaped ones can be sorted out mechanically before the other ones which are more uniform in shape/size are sorted by color . This initial one at a time feeder might snap bananas in half or jam the feeder. I have a theory that this design can be adapted to work with any round or oval shaped candy (M&ms or others) simply by modifying the thickness and hole size of the slider and the surrounding lower portion of the slide. It might also either require a funnel insert to guide smaller candies when the feeder is near empty but might work without it. It also might be worth an adventure into making that portion of the system in OpenSCAD so it's parametric. That's what makes this design so cool, it's very modular. For example, I was looking to see, I think it's possible to just keep adding more sorting sections for more colors if desired. It would very little in the way of mods to make that change.

title: Rainbow Six Siege Bandit Charm Beta

description.text: This is my model of the Bandit Beta Icon Charm from Rainbow Six Siege. The keychain is modified for easy printing.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

MendelMax 1.5

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

2 micron

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Temp: 225
Bed: 100
Material: ABS

Full process

I use Gimp 2 to transform the Bandit Beta Icon into a grayscale image. Then i modified the color B/W levels to get the different "shapes" of the image. One for the bones and bandana, one for the bones in "background" and one for the "black" part of the icon.

After that i use Inkscape to auto-transform those images into 3 svg files.

I imported the 3 svg files in blender and transform them a mesh with each one. Finally, made the keychain model.

author: puhlbo

description.text: This cup is a replicate of a Tuberware coffee cup.

It takes about 2.5 hours to print at the following slice:
2 perimeters
.5mm nozzle
.3 layer height
.3 infill
80mm/sec Clean up after printing.
To make it watertight, coat inside and out with:
SCIGRIP #2354 ABS solvent cement, and let dry for 1 hour.
Test by filling with water, place it on a paper towel and check it in 5 minutes. If it leaks re-coat with the solvent cement. Re-fill with water and leave it overnight. A few of my cups were coated three times.
I have printed over 20 cups using ABS filament extruded on the Lyman Filament Extruder V3, for Xmas stocking stuffers.

description.text:
The lightsaber of the Grand Inquisitor from the first season of Star Wars: Rebels!

One side of the assembly is able to swing over to the other side just like in the show! Sadly, no rotating blades of death though.

Be sure to print:
2 Emitter Shrouds
2 Lower Emitters
2 Middle Emitters
2 Upper Emitters
2 Emitter Guard A's
2 Emitter Guard B's
2 Outer Rotation Chambers
2 Inner Rotation Chambers
2 Small Red Buttons
2 Large Red Buttons

All of the STLs are in the orientation I printed them. Personally, I printed the Outer Ring Right and Left, Inner ring right and left, Outer Rotation Chamber and Middle Grip with support generated in Cura. Feel free to play around with those tricky parts and let me know if you find any better orientation. If you want to swing the outer ring to the other side I would recommend reinforcing the outer rings' joints with glue. There are some tricky parts to this hilt and there are a lot of pieces but the result is super cool!

comments.text: I think the model can be simplified a bit.  As it is, unless I'm doing something very wrong, it doesn't seem to assemble.  I see that the outer rotating chamber and inner rotating chamber are intended to be printed twice, identical.  Also, I see that the emitter shroud's channels are to align with the red buttons.  In that configuration, having a left/right outer ring doesn't actually work.  See the attached picture.

title: Samsung Galaxy S3 dock for pegboard

description.text:
Quick and dirty remix of the dock by frankkienl - chopped it down and put grooves in the bottom to match up to pegboard hooks. I know there are pegboard designs here and I could have printed them in, but this works just as well, and I had a box of spare hooks on hand.

Very tight fit as printed on my old GS3, but since this phone is just for playing music in the shop, it actually works out well. Holds the phone really tight which means it isn't flopping around while I'm trying to hit buttons.

author: Lennie1972

description.text: My Parents bought my daughter a little fishing pole to learn how to cast with and teach her the concept of fishing. Of course the first thing she did was tear off the casting plug it came with and promptly loose it. Sooo I created this. Print it as densely as possible. I printed mine with my "large object" print setup which makes it have very large gaps. as a result it's light as a feather. But it is Functional and just needs to be printed again to make it fly a little farther when cast.

• Print
  • Clean up (there should be a small gap all the way through the fish in the mouth)
  • tie the fishing line through the mouth.
  • cast, Fall asleep.
  • Wake up, reel in, repeat step 4 till the sun starts to set.
  • lie about the size of imaginary fish you caught!!!

remixed_from.author: iamjonlawrence
remixed_from.title: Timing Belt Y MXL, Printrbot Simple V2

title: Timing Belt Y GT2, Printrbot Simple V2

description.text:
This will work for both V2 designs (with & w/o string tension). Included is a fan mount to be compatible with aluminum extruder upgrade. In response to multiple requests I have developed this GT2 timing belt conversion for the Y axis of the Printrbot Simple. This thing is similar to my original http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:180146 Differences are:
  • Use GT2 belt & pulley instead of the MXL
  • Use 608 Bearings instead of R2
  • Requires some modification of the wood Y axis part for the pulley to pass thru. Only needs modification for assembly purposes. After assembly the pulley should clear the stock slot during operation.
    • Benefits:
  • GT2 tooth form
  • Common 608 Bearings
    • Drawbacks:
  • Requires some modification of the stock wood parts
  • Small motor shaft engagement distance. Limit belt tension, otherwise risk pulley not running concentric to shaft and damaging pulley.
    • For anybody having trouble printing these parts I have uploaded a 2014 version to Shapeways if you would like to order them online. http://shpws.me/rbxt This is marked as a work in progress. If you have a success (or failure) please let me know. Feedback is greatly appreciated. REV. A:
  • Shortened motor plate by 2mm
  • Added notch for wrench access to pulley
  • Reduced length of pilot for bearings on motor plate, added pilot for bearings to tie bar. This should allow the bearings to be installed/removed with the pulley in place.
    • REV B:

  • Updated the Belt End Block Rear to accommodate bot the V2 versions. One mounting hole for the version without the Printrbot string tension device and one mounting hole for the current version that includes the string tension device.

  • 2014-01-06: Updated BeltEndBlockGT2Rear for better alignment on Simple model w/String Tension.

  • 2014-01-29: Added BeltEndBlockGT2Front-Fan for those using the early 2014 version Simple with the fan mounted on the side. This will replace the previous BeltEndBlockGT2Front. If your machine has the fan mount included in the Y plate, see next update:

  • 2014-02-25: Added BeltEndBlockGT2Front-2014 for the post-Jan. 15, 2014 machines that have the fan mounting included in the Y plate.

author: PhysUdo

description.text: simple outdoor light for toy house .led can be added to it.

Tired of cleaning out the Shop Vac filters?  
This is something like the Cyclone separators used to catch the big stuff before it ruins your Shop Vac filter.  This worked good enough that I thought it should be here on Thingiverse.  
Fits the standard Shop Vac hose connectors at 58mm.  Mine were pretty snug.  Only one 5 gallon bucket in the picture but I'll be adding a second one inverted with the bottoms cut out and taped together to increase capacity to about 7 gallons.  That should get me through the big jobs on the Planer.

PARTS
3 printed parts from stl's on this page.
Eight #8-32 Machine Screws, 3/4 inch or so.
Four #8-32 nuts
One or Two 5 gallon buckets with lids. Or any 5+ gal bucket with a lid that you may have around. ASSEMBLY
  • Arrange printed parts upside down on the lid and mark the inside of the holes onto the lid. Then cut out holes for the Intake and ToVac parts to drop through the lid.
  • Drill holes in lid for #8 machine using the parts as a guide.
  • Mount Intake with screws and nuts.
  • Mount ToVac to Baffle using 1/2 - 1 inch.#8 Machine screws. Be sure to align the baffle so that the closed off portion is facing the intake. This will prevent the chips from being sucked through to the Vac.
    • Optionally, caulk all the connections to stop air leaks.
    Optionally, add another bucket to the bottom to increase capacity. The single bucket loses efficiency when about half full due to turbulence from the intake. Tip: I've been using the air pressure to hold the lid down during operation so that I don't have to pry it loose when done to empty it. But my intake hose is currently smaller than the one to my Vac so that may not work if the hoses are the same size.

author: claudioscotti

title: Key to Unlocking the Secrets of the Brain

description.text:
OK, this key won't physically unlock the secrets of the brain, but it can be helpful to those in the field of neuroscience. It can be a source of inspiration, inside joke, conversation starter and it even makes a great keychain.

A quick and easy print, this makes a great gift for your local neuroscientist or anyone interested in the mysteries of the brain. Add a split ring and you are all set.

The key has been scaled up from a standard size to something a little more substantial. As such, it will not unlock any locks.

Warning: Do not attempt to unlock your brain by inserting this key into your ear, nose or mouth. That's not how it works.

UPDATE: 7/20/17
I have been having trouble slicing the original file so that it would print without falling apart. I went ahead and added a bit that does deviate from the original key blank more, but it now prints much better and doesn't even require any support. BrainKey_2.0.stl has been posted and BrainKey.stl has been removed.

Developed by Graham Holt at the Laboratories of Cognitive Neuroscience of Boston Children's Hospital.

This object was modeled in TinkerCAD.

comments.text: Thank you for the source file. Your key blade generator is a great resource to make emergency keys. As you said, the blades generated will work as the profiles and cut depths are dead on. I've just enlarged the brain key so that it won't physically fit into a lock any more. However, one could scale it back down and use it if so motivated.
comments.author: LabsOfCognitiveNeuroscience

comments.text: I thought that looked kind of familiar - nice touch!  Maybe I could add the design as an option in the "customizer" ???   BTW - The keys will actually work - but you are correct - they are not very durable - maybe a little WD40 in the lock wouldn't hurt !?!
